poem:
The King's Bentleys, Green

In regal splendor, 
the Bentleys hum,
ghosts of gasoline—
and now, they sip
the sun's bottled breath,
turning tides green,
revelations fold
into a kingly drive,
a slight flick
for feeling less guilty
as we sort our sins
and dreams into bins.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘A real pioneer’: King Charles seeks to embody green values in royal estate A pair of gas-guzzling Bentleys are not the most obvious candidates to burnish the monarch’s green credentials. But news that King Charles is converting his chauffeur-driven luxury vehicles to run on biofuels was this week billed as a small step in a bigger plan to reduce emissions – perhaps the equivalent of lesser mortals separating paper from plastic in the weekly rubbish.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
